instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SSD_RESET_L: What is SSD_RESET_L? SSD_RESET_L is a signal that puts the SSD in reset mode when it is low. This means the SSD will not be accessible when this signal is asserted.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.SSD_PWR_EN: What is SSD_PWR_EN? SSD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip making the power rail for the SSD to turn on when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.SSD_RESET_CONN_L: What is SSD_RESET_CONN_L? SSD_RESET_CONN_L is a signal that goes to the SSD that will put it in RESET mode which will keep it from working, when SSD_RESET_L is present. _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  SSD not Detected
threads.message:
Hi team

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that came because it's not detected the SSD but apparently it had water damage, and someone else tried to cleaned it.
[FONT=Calibri][FONT=arial]After quick inspection: corrosion around <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R7611</RESISTOR> went out of its pace just when I touched it with my twizers so I replaced it.[/FONT]
[FONT=arial]At <CHIP>U3740</CHIP>:[/FONT][/FONT]
pin 1 <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.447V
pin 2 <SIGNAL>P3V3SSD_VMON</SIGNAL>: 1.008V
pin 3 <SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_L</SIGNAL> : 3.291V
pin 4 <SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_CONN_L</SIGNAL> : 3.451V
pin 5 0V
pin 6 <SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>: 3,254V
pin 7 <SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_CONN_L</SIGNAL>: 3,302V
pin 8SSD_CLKREQ_: 3,288V

It's NOT booting with another known good SSD but it is booting on OSX on USB/ external storage, and it's not seeing the SSD in Disk Utility.
Checked <CAPACITOR>C3710</CAPACITOR> to <CAPACITOR>C3717</CAPACITOR> all seems OK.
<SIGNAL>CLK100M_SSD</SIGNAL> oscillation is present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  SSD not Detected
threads.message:
"pin 7 <SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_CONN_L</SIGNAL>: 3,302V"
Did you test with SSD inserted?
If yes, check for corroded trace, or bad contact on J3700.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  SSD not Detected
threads.message:
So I checked te trace and this one is OK,

With the ssd inserted the <SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_CONN_L</SIGNAL> volage is 2.20 V but I tried that ssd in another mba 00165 and I also have a question mark which would mean that that ssd is also faulty.
I took a 100% working ssd and put it in that board the <SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_CONN_L</SIGNAL> voltage is 0V which is OK but still not detected and have a question mark.....
I will pass it in the UC and get back to you.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  SSD not Detected
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_CONN_L</SIGNAL> voltage is 0V which is OK"
Check if <SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> goes also low.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  SSD not Detected
threads.message:
I've passed it into the UC and it's still the same state.
Regarding <SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_CONN_L</SIGNAL> i've posted earlier that it was 0V sorry but in real it's 0.299V which is low state ( again sorry for not being accurate )
for <SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> this one is 1.897V which for me is too high for being considered as "low"

Replaced <CHIP>U3470</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_CONN_L</SIGNAL>: 0.016V
<SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL>: 0.012V
But unfortunately I still have the question mark and the ssd is not detected.

Just hope that the <SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> trace is not broken as it's going directly under the CPU.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  SSD not Detected
threads.message: Start USB OSX and check if Disk Utility recognizes internal SSD at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  SSD not Detected
threads.message:
Already tried after replacing <CHIP>U3470</CHIP>  and it's not seen in disk utility.
I tried to re program the bios but now it's not turning ON at all. 
I'll have to re flash it back with its original dump that I backed up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  SSD not Detected
threads.message: Check <CHIP>U3710</CHIP>/11 and their connections with J3700.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  SSD not Detected
threads.message:
So I've reflashed it back with original dump and many other also but the board now is not turning ON at all.
CPU area getting hot but not burning

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 8.58v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> : 3.381V
[B]<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> : 2.721 V[/B]
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> : 5.011V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.254VV
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>: 0V

[B]<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>[/B] line is directly attached to <CHIP>U0500</CHIP>, which is getting hot, it's maybe shorted to gnd somewhere......under <CHIP>U0500</CHIP>.....
Is it possible that the CPU fried just by taken the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> out/in.......hummmm?
just for comparaison these are the voltages for the same rails when the board arrived to me:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 8.59v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> : 3.432V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> : 3.317V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> : 5.011V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  SSD not Detected
threads.message:
CPU cannot get hot in S5 state.
You've messed something when desolder/resolder SPI chip.
PCH seems to be damaged now...

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is generated by <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>; does it get hot too?
<CHIP>U0500</CHIP> stays cold if you remove <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  SSD not Detected
threads.message:
I will check that, in the mean time i was working on connections from J3700 to <CHIP>U3710</CHIP>/11 and:
from pin 2 of 3711 to pin 51 of J3700 it 0.4 Ohms
from pin 4 of <CHIP>U3710</CHIP> to pin 52 of J3700 it was 2 Ohms so I've put a direct trace now it's 0.4 Ohm....

Now i have to figure out why the <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is dropping to 2.721V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  SSD not Detected
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> is not getting hot
<CHIP>U0500</CHIP> continue to be hot even if <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> is removed......

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  SSD not Detected
threads.message:
I removed the heat sink and the PCH side is burning hot, I cannot let the finger on it.
I tried a reflow without success.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  SSD not Detected
threads.message: PCH dead, your board is trash now :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  SSD not Detected
threads.message:

I'll have to find a solution for the client......pffffff :mad:
